captions.text:
When it comes to neighbors, most countries
have several options: like North to Canada
or South to Mexico.

But there are countries that don't have this
freedom of choice, not because they're islands

but because they're trapped in another country.
For example: tiny Vatican City, which fits
inside of not just Italy, but also just Rome.

How Vatican City got surrounded is complicated,
but not unique for there is also the Republic

of San Marino, home to 30,000 citizens which
Italy also completely surrounds. Italy, apparently,
is a country that likes countries in its country.

But trapping nations is not just Italy's thing
for there's also Lesotho, in South Africa

which is both the largest encircled country
at 70 times Vatican City's size and the most
populated with over 2,000,000 citizens.

The thing that makes these three countries'
borders bizarre is that any path in or out

must go through the one and only neighbor
they have.

But now take a look at The Gambia, which excluding
that tiny ocean border, is as surrounded as
any nation can get.

If we amend the previous rule to every land
route, now we've made a category of single-neighbored

nations. Which includes all four of these
and countries like Portugal, where the only

way in or out is through Spain. Who else is
on this list?

Well, there's Monaco which must go through
France, Qatar through Saudi Arabia Denmark

through Germany, South Korea through North
Korea (though South Korea might as well be

an island nation for most practical travel
purposes)

East Timor and Papua New Guinea both through
Indonesia, Brunei through Malaysia

And there are two sets of twins: there is
The Dominican Republic whose only neighbor

is Haiti and Haiti, whose only neighbor is
The Dominican Republic.

And the second set is: Ireland through the
United Kingdom and the United Kingdom through
Ireland.
A side note here:

While there are tons of 'British' places around
the world, some of which border other nations

-- these are not part of the United Kingdom.
It's complicated.

Though if you wanted to, you could argue that
the United Kingdom technically dug a land

border under the channel to the continent,
presumably to be closer to France, her best
friend ever.

Finally, there's one more country in this
category: Canada: the largest single-neighbored,
nation in the world.

title: Countries inside Countries: Bizarre Borders Part 1

comments.author: BestDucky “BestDuckyRBLX” RBLX

comments.text:
+BestDucky RBLX St. Pierre and Miquelon are both French territories that 
are off of the New Brunswick coast.
I didn't make up the embassy thing, in theory you did. You say that Hans 
island is a land border between Canada and Greenland, when in reality, 
because of it's size, it isn't. You can relate that same manner to 
embassies. Many countries border other countries that are halfway across 
the world from each other because of embassies in their country.
You also don't get what water borders mean. Water borders relate to inland 
waters, not sea or oceanic waters. If water borders included sea or oceanic 
water borders, Australia would border New Guinea, Japan with Russia, USA 
with Russia, Spain and Morocco, Qatar with Yemen etc. This would also 
include Canada with France, because of New Brunswick bordering the French 
territories of St. Pierre and Miquelon. 
Also the Mercator projection is inaccurate. It depicts Greenland about the 
same size of Africa, when in reality Africa is roughly 14 times larger than 
Greenland. 
So it goes to show, you're illiterate to an extent, because you thought 
that I meant New Brunswick was a French territory somehow, and don't know 
simple terms and definitions.
comments.author: Pyroxidy

comments.text:
+Pyroxidy Uh, where did you got out that New Brunswick is a french 
territory?

You totally made up that embassy part and it's actually utterly ignorant, 
goob job calling me not that smart.
comments.author: BestDucky “BestDuckyRBLX” RBLX

comments.text:
+BestDucky RBLX If inland waters are excluded, a country can not have water 
borders with another country. The UN doesn't count water border (excluding 
inland waters such as lakes and rivers) as area of the country itself. 
Canada doesn't have borders with Greenland, in the same way that Canada 
doesn't have borders with Russia to the north, and the US with Russia with 
the Alaskan islands, or even for that matter Canada and France with the 
island of New Brunswick and St. Pierre and Miquelon. Hans island also isn't 
really considered a border either, even though it is Canadian and 
Greenlandic land on the island. Again, the same way Vimmy Ridge is a part 
of Canada in France, it doesn't 'border' France legally. For fucks sake you 
can bring the argument over even with embassies.... Technically Canada 
borders China, Japan. UK, Poland, Germany, South Africa, Australia, etc. by 
your definition. You're not that smart buddy.

He left out tons of sovereign native American nations in the U.S. and

comments.author: d1p

comments.text:
+tommykl The designation of "nation" is often treated like this. Many areas 
that would be considered a nation realistically, (such as Indian Reserves, 
autonomous regions within Middle Eastern and African countries, and Hong 
Kong, as well as rebellious groups and territories, such as the Islamic 
State,) are often not consider nations due to politics, despite evidence to 
the contrary. Calling an Indian Reserve a nation would make the US mad 
(that's a bad idea!) Calling the Islamic State a nation would make almost 
everyone in the world mad.

Indian reserves have tried to appeal to the UN to be recognized as 
independent to the US. For instance, the Oglala Lakota, attempted to reform 
their government to oust a very corrupt leader. They appealed to the US 
government, but the US said they were sovereign and didn't help. So, they 
tried to do it themselves, and the FBI and US Marshals laid siege on them. 
In response, they appealed to the UN, but it was an understandably risky 
position for foreign relations. 3 people died in the siege, but over 60 
political opponents of their corrupt leader died violent deaths after the 
incident. 

Moral of the story is, you are considered a separate country on the world 
stage only if your neighboring countries couldn't eradicate you in an 
instant if they wanted.
comments.author: d1p

comments.text:
+d1p The point here is that these Indian nations, while sovereign over 
their own territory, aren't officially recognised as such by other 
countries. They pretty much agree that they have control, but they're not 
considered a separate country. I think the best other example of this 
outside of other aboriginal nations is possibly Greenland?
comments.author: tommykl

comments.text:
+General Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington. The name "reservation" 
comes from the conception of the Indian tribes as independent sovereigns at 
the time the U.S. Constitution was ratified. Thus, the early peace treaties 
(often signed under duress) in which Indian tribes surrendered large 
portions of land to the U.S. also designated parcels which the tribes, as 
sovereigns, "reserved" to themselves, and those parcels came to be called 
"reservations." The term remained in use even after the federal government 
began to forcibly relocate tribes to parcels of land to which they had no 
historical connection. Indian reservations are sovereign, as per treaty. 
Not that the US actually follows said treaties.
comments.author: d1p

comments.text: Navajo nation isn't a country. It's an Indian reserve.
